Expectation1: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation1: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the project plan half-finished. My manager’s email sat at the top of my inbox, marked urgent: “We need your time estimates for the quarterly roadmap by noon.” I knew how much the team relied on my input—if I delayed, the whole planning process would stall. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the food pantry started in thirty minutes. I’d promised to be there, and I hated the idea of letting the coordinator down. Still, I also knew that, at the pantry, a few extra hands could cover for me if I was late. At work, though, my absence would be glaring. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility I felt as an engineer and the commitment I’d made as a volunteer. I could feel the pressure building in my chest, the weight of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
